dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#TaxonBiology
dataObjects.description: Painter's mussels received their name from the days when painters used their shells to save their paint in. The two valves of the mussel fit exactly together, forming a firmly closed box. Small fish, such as bitterlings, lay their eggs in these mussels.

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#TaxonBiology
dataObjects.description: De schildersmossel heeft zijn naam gekregen omdat schilders vroeger de schelpen gebruikten om hun verf in te bewaren. De twee kleppen van de schildersmossel passen precies op elkaar, waardoor ze een mooi afgesloten doosje vormen. Visjes zoals de bittervoorn leggen hun eitjes in schildersmossels.

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObjects.title: Range Description
dataObjects.rights: © International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources
dataObjects.rightsHolder: International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources
dataObjects.bibliographicCitation: Van Damme, D. 2011. Unio pictorum. In: IUCN 2014 . IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Version 2014.1 . <www.iucnredlist.org>
dataObjects.description: This species is widely distributed throughout Europe and Russia (Fauna Europaea 2004). It is found in north and northwestern Europe, central and eastern Europe to the Ural region and the Black and Caspian Sea basins (Van Damme pers. comm. 2011). It is absent from Scotland and rare in northern England and Wales, but is found throughout central, southern, western and eastern Europe (Fauna Europaea 2004). It is also absent from Spain and Portugal (Van Damme pers. comm. 2011). Kantor et al. (2009) list the species as being distributed throughout western Transcaucasia (Georgia, Russia, Turkey), the Ural river, Danube basin and to the Ukraine.

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat
dataObjects.title: Habitat and Ecology
dataObjects.rights: © International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources
dataObjects.rightsHolder: International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources
dataObjects.bibliographicCitation: Van Damme, D. 2011. Unio pictorum. In: IUCN 2014 . IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Version 2014.1 . <www.iucnredlist.org>
dataObjects.description:
Habitat and Ecology
This species lives in calcareous waters in large, slow-flowing rivers, canals, lakes and reservoirs in lowlands. Occasionally it is also found in ponds, oxbows and flooded gravel pits. Populations tend to be concentrated in marginal zones of large rivers where firm, muddy substrate is available, but it is found less commonly in sand, fine gravels and soft mud (Aldridge 1999).

Systems
  • Freshwater

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Conservation
dataObjects.title: IUCN Red List Assessment
dataObjects.rights: © International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources
dataObjects.rightsHolder: International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources
dataObjects.bibliographicCitation: Van Damme, D. 2011. Unio pictorum. In: IUCN 2014 . IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Version 2014.1 . <www.iucnredlist.org>
dataObjects.description:
Red List Category
LC
Least Concern

Red List Criteria

Version
3.1

Year Assessed
2011

Assessor/s
Van Damme, D.

Reviewer/s
Böhm, M. & Collen, B.

Contributor/s

Justification
Unio pictorum has been assessed as Least Concern. Despite some local declines being observed and continuing threat processes impacting the species, it has a widespread distribution and is tolerant to poor conditions currently demonstrating a stable global population.

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Trends
dataObjects.title: Population
dataObjects.rights: © International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources
dataObjects.rightsHolder: International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources
dataObjects.bibliographicCitation: Van Damme, D. 2011. Unio pictorum. In: IUCN 2014 . IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Version 2014.1 . <www.iucnredlist.org>
dataObjects.description:
Population

There is no information available on the population trends of this species. There is some evidence of local regional decline in south-east and northern England, as well as in Scotland, but this decline may simply be an artefact of a lack of recording effort. The species has an average age of nine years, suggesting 30 years as a suitable assessment period (Bauer and Wächtler 2001). It is fairly abundant throughout its distribution. Local forms are continuously replaced by uniform forms introduced by gamefish (Falkner 1990; Cucherat 2003).


Population Trend
Unknown

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Threats
dataObjects.title: Threats
dataObjects.rights: © International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources
dataObjects.rightsHolder: International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources
dataObjects.bibliographicCitation: Van Damme, D. 2011. Unio pictorum. In: IUCN 2014 . IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Version 2014.1 . <www.iucnredlist.org>
dataObjects.description:
Major Threats

Several major threat processes negatively impact this species, including river (or canal) modification, river and canal management (dredging and weed cutting), destruction or over-dredging of large ponds and lakes, water quality decline, tourism and development pressure (e.g., marinas), competition or direct mortalities due to exotic species. This species has also been documented as being sensitive to biodegradeable pollution (Mouthon 1996), although its UK distribution has suggested higher levels of tolerance as it has been found to be the sole large mussel species found immediately downstream of sewage outfalls (Killeen et al. 2004).

This species is also vulnerable to the continued spread of the introduced zebra mussels (Dreissena polymorpha) (Bauer and Wächtler 2001). It is also theratened by genetic pollution as introductions of game fish to European rivers means that characteristic local forms are continuously replaced with uniform forms (Falkner 1990; Cucherat 2003).

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Management
dataObjects.title: Conservation Actions
dataObjects.rights: © International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources
dataObjects.rightsHolder: International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources
dataObjects.bibliographicCitation: Van Damme, D. 2011. Unio pictorum. In: IUCN 2014 . IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Version 2014.1 . <www.iucnredlist.org>
dataObjects.description:
Conservation Actions
There are no known conservation measures in place for this species This species is considered as Least Concern in the UK, but Near Threatened in Sweden as a result of habitat fragmentation and a range decrease of 25% (Fauna Europaea 2004). Further research is recommended into the population trends of this species across its wide range, and habitat monitoring may be beneficial as an early warning system for habitat quality decreases.
